utterances: Simply because it's fun to listen to.
I think the worst thing we can do is present jazz as a form of musical spinach that, you know, listen to it, it's good for you.
You know, it's simply great music that's fun to listen to.
And anybody who's motivated to find music of whatever description that's fun to listen to should seek it out.
Well I think, too, that if we compare this to people who are interested in wine, you know, there's people who are connoisseurs of fine wine and people who drink wine out of a screw-top bottle.
But jazz, the musicians themselves are brilliant.
And as you get more into jazz, you realize, my gosh, how does that guy play this way?
When we listen to Louis Armstrong, where did he come up with that?
And it continues and it spirals and it grabs you.

And once you realize that all the skills and the years and the polish and the practicing and how it comes down into just making beautiful music, that's the fun bag at the pot of the - the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
Well, gentlemen, it's been great talking to you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
David Schroeder is the director of jazz studies at New York University's Steinhardt School and a member of the jazz group Combo Nuevo.
He spoke with us from NPR's New York studios.
Bill Kirschner is a jazz educator, historian, musician and composer.
And Eugene Holley, Jr. is a freelance jazz reviewer and columnist.
From the studios of NPR West, this is Day to Day.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Coming up, bonfire of the hedge funds.
We talk with novelist Tom Wolfe about the future of the financial wizards he dubbed the, ""Masters of the Universe"".
First though, as it finally comes to an end, a quick look back at what maybe the most dramatic month in financial history.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH (United States of America): This is an extraordinary period for America's economy.
The government is taking over Fannie and Freddie.

Delay Friday night's debate.

Tightened down.
That, say the experts, is the problem.
They talked about a freeze in the commercial paper market.
The commercial paper market, that's short-term loans for businesses, the grease that keeps the wheels turning in the economy and perhaps the most important capital in capitalism.
To help us understand what's happening in the credit market, we called Andy Serwer.
He's the managing editor of Fortune magazine.
He says while all eyes are on the stock market, people should really be worried about commercial paper.
This is kind of the business commercial paper of companies lending money to each other.
And they do it in very short-terms, which is just a matter of 30 days or so.
And what's happening right now is businesses and banks are unwilling to lend to each other, or if they are it's at much, much higher rates.
It's fear and behind the scenes, the wheels are kind of grinding to a halt.
So basically, a company that perhaps needs to borrow on a short-term basis to meet payroll, a company like that could find itself without money to pay its workers?
Yeah.
I want to be very careful.
I mean, I don't think we're at a situation right now where, you know, companies are going to go broke simply because they can't borrow money short-term.
But it wouldn't surprise me if, you know, a company that's kind of close to the edge is unable to get financing, or something like that.
That's right.
This is a real situation that could turn ugly.
And I think that it's very hard for people to kind of wrap their brains around it because it is sort of the hidden side of the economy.
You know, they can see the stock market tumbling and that's bad, but this is actually just as bad, if not worse.
Where else would ordinary Americans feel the pain?
We're hearing all kinds of anecdotal stories of, you know, rates going up, of banks not willing to lend, of credit tightening.
And so, you know, if you wanted to go buy a tractor, I'm sure you could go down to your John Deere dealer and get one.
But I would be surprised if the rate on the financing of that tractor wasn't a bit higher than it was six months ago.
Second, ends - E-N-D-S - and personality.
Split.
Well, very important, Farai, because the U.S.
believes - and I shouldn't just say the U.S.
believes - that the international community believes that East Africa could be a breeding ground for terrorist who could have some effect on the West and on other areas of the world.
Osama bin Laden received help from the Sudanese government back in the 1990s.
And, as you know, Somalia has not had a government for about 15 years now.
So it has really been a state of nature there.
So anyone could likely go to Somalia and set up shop there with the most nefarious of interest and be allowed to operate unabatedly.

So it's been important for the international community to try to keep an eye on what's going on in this region of the world, in East Africa, because so little of this area, geographically, is under anyone's oversight.
You can go to areas of Somalia or Sudan and you can travel for hundreds of miles and you will not see one local authority, for instance.
This is an ongoing mystery, what's happening in East Africa, and it's very difficult, not only for U.S.
governmental interest, but also for all watchers of the area to really get a hand on what's going on, which of course makes everyone feel a little bit more unsettled.
Speaking of unsettled, a suicide bomber reportedly struck in front of the prime minister's house in Mogadishu in Somalia.
Does anyone know who planned that explosion?

Any number of agents could have been behind the attack over the weekend, Farai, essentially, the transitional government in Somalia, which is still fighting to gain control over that country as well as Prime Minister Gedi.
They've got an awful lot of enemies.
They've got enemies from the outside in terms of, perhaps, those who are sympathetic with the Islamic Courts Union, who used to control Mogadishu.
These agents might be acting against the transitional government and in the form of an insurgency that they've likened to the insurgency in Iraq.

There are also domestic tensions on the ground, specifically the clans, who really have very little to say to the prime minister, most specifically his own clan - the Hawiye - who were the dominant clan of the Islamic Courts Union and who are the most militarily-supported of all the clans.
They're the strongest.
They're the most powerful.
And, unfortunately, they don't seem to have much regard for the prime minister.
Well, Gwen, that seems like a lot of serious bad news in one week.
Well, you're right, Farai, it does seem like an awful lot of bad news, but there have been other reports that are a little bit more encouraging.
Here in Kenya, reports are showing 6.1 percent, a growth in the GDP, which is phenomenal.
I mean, this economy is growing at a rate that it hasn't grown at since the 1970s.

And in large part, it's believed that tourism has been the engine behind this kind of growth - tourism in the form of conferences, conferees staying a few extra days going on safari here, looking at other sites.
